results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

results.title: The Legend of the pied piper

video_links.name: The Legend of the pied piper

results.brief_description: One of a series of films in which puppets are used to interpret folk legends. This film is an adaptation of the well-known fairy story of how the master musician drove the rats from the city of Hamelin.

results.title: Learning Through Play
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Alexander, Don Hauser, World Organisation for early Childhood Development and Monash University
results.brief_description: Looks at play amongst three year-olds and the more highly developed and realistic play of five year-olds. Shows the role of the teacher in various situations providing challenging equipment to extend the interests of the children and in guiding play to complement structured learning.

results.title: The International Court of Justice
results.creator_credit: Karl Van der Ploeg, Janine Hamel-Minne and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description: The origin of the concept of international law and the evolvement of the role of the International Court of Justice in the Hague, in deciding legal disputes between States. Its work and function are illustrated in the controversy between Norway and the United Kingdom concerning fishing rights, the disputed frontier land between Belgium and the Netherlands, and the dispute between Cambodia and Thailand regarding the territorial sovereignty of a holy monastery.

results.title: The Importance of flow in furrow irrigation

video_links.name: The Importance of flow in furrow irrigation

results.brief_description: Shows how the three aims of controlled irrigation can be achieved in furrow irrigation by putting the “correct flow” down the furrows so as to obtain even distribution of the water over the whole area and down to the depth of the root zone. The various factors which determine “correct flow” are briefly considered and finally the method whereby it may be obtained and checked is outlined.

results.title: Handle with care: glass
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A brief history of the Indian glass industry, contrasting the products of the individual artisan and the modern streamlined factory. To aid the industry, the Government established the Central Glass and ceramic Research Institute in Calcutta to conduct research into new types of glass.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Glassmakers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
A survey of the wide range of glass products manufactured by British craftsmen. Includes manufacture of plate glass and installation of a large sheet in one of the Festival of Britain buildings; making of stained glass windows; manufacture of optical glass and lenses; prisms and lanterns for lighthouses; production of electric light globes; glass blowing and making of nahd0made cut glass.

results.title: Daylight saving sleep schedule
results.brief_description: They say it takes a village, and the village it seems has moved online, with countless parental bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets offers a moment of reprieve, with his hilariously honest posts making light of the early years of baby raising. And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

They say it takes a village and the village its seems has moved online, with countless parental bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets offers a moment reprieve, with his hilariously honest posts making light of the early years of baby raising. And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?
description_for_label: They say it takes a village and the village its seems has moved online, with countless parental bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets offers a moment reprieve, with his hilariously honest posts making light of the early years of baby raising. And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Money movement mindset
results.brief_description: Annoying finance bros beware: the comedians are coming for your grindset! Financial planning is a popular podcast and video genre online — but many of them are hosted by young men whose views on how to make bank can be hilariously macho, and based on an unrealistic picture of how and why most people spend their money. In this video, Tiktok comedian Caroline Baniewicz skewers finance bro culture, satirising the impractical ways that these podcasters advise on making your first million.
results.description: Annoying finance bros beware: the comedians are coming for your grindset! Financial planning is a popular podcast and video genre online — many of them hosted by young men whose views on how to make bank can be hilariously macho and out of touch. In this video, Tiktok comedian Caroline Baniewicz skewers finance bro culture, satirising the impractical ways that these podcasters advise on making your first million.
description_for_label: Annoying finance bros beware: the comedians are coming for your grindset! Financial planning is a popular podcast and video genre online — many of them hosted by young men whose views on how to make bank can be hilariously macho and out of touch. In this video, Tiktok comedian Caroline Baniewicz skewers finance bro culture, satirising the impractical ways that these podcasters advise on making your first million.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 7 - Violet
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 7 – Violet was broadcast as the seventh of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Third Eye ‘Ambi Jam’ (Gus Till, Ollie Olsen, Geoffrey Hales, Simon Polinski), Cyberdada (Troy Innocent & Dale Nason), Phuture (Crissie Seivers and M. Buchanan ‘Equinox Comics’), Stelarc, Theatre TV (Eliza, Mari Giambanco and Julie Turner), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), Corruption & Vice (Ju-Ann Lam), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) and Dont Shoot The Messenger (Steve Middleton)

Cyberthon VII: Spectrum 7 – Violet is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.
